pending_diagnosis: This case demonstrates a classic, devastating presentation of a life-threatening acute metabolic crisis, often misdiagnosed as purely psychiatric or neurological until it's too late. DIAGNOSIS: Acute Intermittent Porphyria (AIP) THE SMOKING GUN: The combination of severe, unexplained abdominal pain, profound acute polyneuropathy, psychiatric symptoms (hallucinations/agitation), autonomic instability (tachycardia/hypertension), and the trigger (Sulfonamide antibiotic), confirmed by the urine darkening upon standing. PATHOPHYSIOLOGY: Acute Intermittent Porphyria is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a partial deficiency of the enzyme Porphobilinogen Deaminase (PBGD), also known as Hydroxymethylbilane Synthase. This enzyme deficiency causes a bottleneck in the heme synthesis pathway. When triggered by certain drugs (like sulfonamides, barbiturates, or alcohol), starvation, or hormonal changes, the upstream intermediates—specifically Porphobilinogen (PBG) and Delta-Aminolevulinic Acid (ALA)—accumulate in massive quantities. These precursors are neurotoxic. The clinical manifestations stem entirely from this neurotoxicity: 1. Abdominal pain: Due to visceral autonomic neuropathy/spasm. 2. Hypertension/Tachycardia: Due to sympathetic overactivity. 3. Peripheral Neuropathy (flaccid paralysis): Due to axonal damage. 4. Psychiatric Symptoms: Direct toxicity on the CNS. Confirmation requires testing for elevated urinary ALA and PBG, which will be profoundly high during an acute attack. Treatment involves withdrawal of the offending agent, high-dose glucose infusion, and, crucially, intravenous hematin (Heme Arginitate) to suppress ALA synthase activity and thus slow the production of the toxic intermediates.
